natural problem: The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8?
natural solution: We can look at the terms of the Lucas sequence modulo 8. \begin{align} L_1 &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_2 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_3 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_4 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_5 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_6 &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\

L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\

L_{15} &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{16} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}. \end{align}Since $L_{13}=1$ and $L_{14}=3$, the sequence begins repeating at the 13th term, so it repeats every 12 terms. Since the remainder is 4 when we divide 100 by 12, we know $L_{100}\equiv L_4\pmod 8$.
Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 1"
and h1 : "f 2 = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>n \<ge> 3. f n = f (n-1) + f (n-2)"
shows  "f 100 mod 8 = 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 We can look at the terms of the Lucas sequence modulo 8. \begin{align} L_1 &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_2 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_3 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_4 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_5 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_6 &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\
 L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\
 L_{15} &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{16} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}. \end{align}Since $L_{13}=1$ and $L_{14}=3$, the sequence begins repeating at the 13th term, so it repeats every 12 terms. Since the remainder is 4 when we divide 100 by 12, we know $L_{100}\equiv L_4\pmod 8$.
 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 1"
and h1 : "f 2 = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>n \<ge> 3. f n = f (n-1) + f (n-2)"
shows  "f 100 mod 8 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a function $f$ defined as follows: $f(1)=1$, $f(2)=3$ and for all natural numbers $n \geq 3$, $f(n) = f(n-1) + f(n-2)$. What is the remainder when $f(100)$ is divided by 8? The final answer is 7.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "Lucas 1 = 1"
and h1 : "Lucas 2 = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> Lucas n = Lucas (n - 1) + Lucas (n - 2)"
shows  "Lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8? The final Answer is 7

 L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\
 L_{15} &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{16} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}. \end{align}Since $L_{13}=1$ and $L_{14}=3$, the sequence begins repeating at the 13th term, so it repeats every 12 terms. Since the remainder is 4 when we divide 100 by 12, we know $L_{100}\equiv L_4\pmod 8$.
 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes Lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "Lucas 1 = 1"
and h1 : "Lucas 2 = 3"

shows  "Lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"

a_2.formal problem:
function lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
  "lucas 0 = 1"
| "lucas 1 = 3"
| "lucas (n + 2) = lucas n + lucas (n + 1)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "measure id") auto

theorem
shows  "lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 We can look at the terms of the Lucas sequence modulo 8. \begin{align} L_1 &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_2 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_3 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_4 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_5 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_6 &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\
 L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\
 L_{15} &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{16} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}. \end{align}Since $L_{13}=1$ and $L_{14}=3$, the sequence begins repeating at the 13th term, so it repeats every 12 terms. Since the remainder is 4 when we divide 100 by 12, we know $L_{100}\equiv L_4\pmod 8$.
 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

function lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
  "lucas 0 = 1"
| "lucas 1 = 3"
| "lucas (n + 2) = lucas n + lucas (n + 1)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "measure id") auto

theorem
shows  "lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

assumes h0 : "lucas 1 = 1"

function Lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
"Lucas 1 = 1"
| "Lucas 2 = 3"
| "Lucas n = Lucas (n-1) + Lucas (n-2)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "Wellfounded.measure (\<lambda>n. n)") auto

theorem
shows  "(Lucas 100) mod 8 = 7"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8? The final Answer is 7

 We can look at the terms of the Lucas sequence modulo 8. \begin{align} L_1 &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_2 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_3 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_4 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_5 &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_6 &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\

 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

where
"Lucas 1 = 1"
| "Lucas 2 = 3"
| "Lucas n = Lucas (n-1) + Lucas (n-2)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "Wellfounded.measure (\<lambda>n. n)") auto

function lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
"lucas 0 = 0" |
"lucas 1 = 1" |
"lucas n = (lucas (n-1)) + (lucas (n-2))"

theorem
assumes h0 : "n = 100"
shows  "lucas n mod 8 = 7"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Lucas sequence is the sequence 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, $\ldots$ where the first term is 1, the second term is 3 and each term after that is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 8? The final Answer is 7

 L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\
 L_{15} &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{16} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}. \end{align}Since $L_{13}=1$ and $L_{14}=3$, the sequence begins repeating at the 13th term, so it repeats every 12 terms. Since the remainder is 4 when we divide 100 by 12, we know $L_{100}\equiv L_4\pmod 8$.
 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

function lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
"lucas 0 = 0" |
"lucas 1 = 1" |
"lucas n = (lucas (n-1)) + (lucas (n-2))"

assumes h0 : "n = 100"
shows  "lucas n mod 8 = 7"

where

where
"Lucas 0 = 1" |
"Lucas 1 = 3" |
"Lucas (Suc (Suc n)) = Lucas (Suc n) + Lucas n"

shows  "Lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"
a_9.formal solution:

 L_7 &\equiv 5\pmod{8}, \\ L_8 &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_9 &\equiv 4\pmod{8}, \\ L_{10} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\ L_{11} &\equiv 7\pmod{8}, \\ L_{12} &\equiv 2\pmod{8}, \\ L_{13} &\equiv 1\pmod{8}, \\ L_{14} &\equiv 3\pmod{8}, \\

 Therefore the remainder when $L_{100}$ is divided by 8 is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

primrec Lucas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
"Lucas 0 = 1" |
"Lucas 1 = 3" |
"Lucas (Suc (Suc n)) = Lucas (Suc n) + Lucas n"

theorem 
shows  "Lucas 100 mod 8 = 7"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
